10. Proof. We omit (a) since is standard. For (b), if $u$ attains an interior maximum, then the conclusion follows from strong maximum principle. 
If not, then for some $x^{0}\in\partial U,u(x^{0})>u(x)\forall x\in U$ . Then Hopf’s lemma implies $\begin{array}{r}{\frac{\partial u}{\partial\nu}(x^{0})>0}\end{array}$ , which is a contradiction. 口 
Remark 2. A generalization of this problem to mixed boundary conditions is recorded in Gilbarg-Trudinger, Elliptic PDEs of second order, Problem 3.1. 
11. Proof. Define 
$$
B[u,v]=\int_{U}\sum_{i,j}a^{i j}u_{x_{i}}v_{x_{j}}d x{\mathrm{~for~}}u\in H^{1}(U),v\in H_{0}^{1}(U).
$$
By Exercise 5.17, $\phi(u)\in H^{1}(U)$ . Then, for all $v\in C_{c}^{\infty}(U),v\geq0$ , 
$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{B[\phi(u),v]=\displaystyle\int_{U}\sum_{i,j}a^{i j}(\phi(u))_{x_{i}}v_{x_{j}}d x}\ &{\quad\quad\quad=\displaystyle\int_{U}\sum_{i,j}a^{i j}\phi^{\prime}(u)u_{x_{i}}v_{x_{j}}d x,\mathrm{~}(\phi^{\prime}(u)\mathrm{~is~bounded~since~u~is~bounded})}\ &{\quad\quad\quad=\displaystyle\int_{U}\sum_{i,j}a^{i j}u_{x_{i}}(\phi^{\prime}(u)v)_{x_{j}}-\sum_{i,j}a_{i j}\phi^{\prime\prime}(u)u_{x_{i}}u_{x_{j}}v d x}\ &{\quad\quad\quad\quad\le0-\displaystyle\int_{U}\phi^{\prime\prime}(u)v|D u|^{2}d x\le0,\mathrm{~by~convexity~of~}\phi.}\end{array}
$$
(We don’t know whether the product of two $H^{1}$ functions is weakly differentiable. This is why we do not take $v\in H_{0}^{1}$ .) Now we complete the proof with the standard density argument. 
12. Proof. Given $u\in C^{2}(U)\cap C(U)$ with $L u\le0$ in $U$ and $u\leq0$ on $\partial U$ . Since $U$ is compact and $v\in C(\bar{U}),v\geq c>0$ . So $\begin{array}{r}{w:=\frac{u}{v}\in C^{2}(U)\cap C(U)}\end{array}$ . Brutal computation gives us 
$$
\begin{array}{l}{{-a^{i j}w_{x_{i}x_{j}}=\displaystyle{\frac{-a^{i j}u_{x_{i}x_{j}}v+a^{i j}v_{x_{i}x_{j}}u}{v^{2}}+\frac{a^{i j}v_{x_{i}}u_{x_{j}}-a^{i j}u_{x_{i}}v_{x_{j}}}{v^{2}}-a^{i j}\displaystyle{\frac{2}{v}v_{x_{j}}\frac{v_{x_{i}}u-v u_{x_{i}}}{v^{2}}}}}\ {{\displaystyle{\phantom{-}=\displaystyle{\frac{(L u-b^{i}u_{x_{i}}-c u)v+(-L v+b^{i}v_{x_{i}}+c v)u}{v^{2}}+0+a^{i j}\displaystyle{\frac{2}{v}v_{x_{j}}w_{x_{i}},\mathrm{~since~}a^{i j}=\frac{\sum v_{x_{i}}\omega_{x_{i}}}{v^{2}}}}}\quad}\ {{\displaystyle{\phantom{-}=\displaystyle{\frac{L u}{v}-\frac{u L v}{v^{2}}-b^{i}w_{x_{i}}+a^{i j}\displaystyle{\frac{2}{v}v_{x_{j}}w_{x_{i}}}}}}\end{array}
$$
Therefore, 
$$
M w:=-a^{i j}w_{x_{i}x_{j}}+w_{x_{i}}\bigl[b^{i}-a^{i j}\frac{2}{v}v_{x_{j}}\bigr]=\frac{L u}{v}-\frac{u L v}{v^{2}}\leq0\mathrm{on}\{x\in\bar{U}:u>0\}\subseteq U
$$
If $\{x\in U:u>0\}$ is not empty, Weak maximum principle to the operator $M$ with bounded coefficeints (since $v\in C^{1}(U)$ ) will lead a contradiction that 
$$
0<\operatorname*{max}_{\{u>0\}}w=\operatorname*{max}_{\partial\{u>0\}}w=\frac{0}{v}=0
$$
Hence $u\leq0$ in $\boldsymbol{U}$ .
